ygData.subject: Re: [rest-discuss] What method to apply to a 'link'?
ygData.msgSnippet: Actually, this is on my to-do list under the name RDF Forms . Basically, a way to declare parameterized (not just NV pairs) state transitions via GET or POST

Actually, this is on my to-do list under the name "RDF Forms".

Basically, a way to declare parameterized (not just NV pairs) state
transitions via GET or POST (or extended POST), just like HTML forms,
only for RDF and SOAP.

It shouldn't be too difficult, I don't believe.  I just have to get
off my a$$.

MB

On Sun, May 18, 2003 at 10:15:09PM +0200, Jan Algermissen wrote:
> When a web service returns some XML encoded representation to
> a client adn this XML is containing XLinks to other resources,
> how could the web service provide information what methods to
> use in the request to those resources?
> 
> In http://www.prescod.net/rest/state_transition.html Paul
> Prescod uses the example HTTP reply
> 
> 200 OK
> 
> <challenge><p>Stop! 
> Who would cross the Bridge of Death must answer me 
> these questions three, 
> ere the other side he see. 
> Do you agree?</p>
> <method>POST</method> your answer in             <------------**
> <uri>/sessions</uri></challenge>
> 
> which to me implies that <method> is a specialized element
> used in this interaction. Is there a way something like this
> could be used with/added to XLink to be understood be every software
> that supports XLink?
> 
> Other thoughts?
> 
> 
> Jan
> 
> 
>
